speaker: SAMPSON
content: He declares they will not endure insults, as 'carry coals' means to tolerate abuse.

speaker: GREGORY
content: He agrees, joking that if they did, they would be coal-carriers, which was a lowly job.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He says if they become angry ('in choler'), they will draw their swords.

speaker: GREGORY
content: He puns on 'draw', suggesting Sampson should draw his neck out of a hangman's collar instead.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He boasts that he strikes swiftly when provoked.

speaker: GREGORY
content: He retorts that Sampson is not easily provoked to fight.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He claims a Montague dog would provoke him.

speaker: GREGORY
content: He twists Sampson's words, saying to be moved is to run away, but to be brave is to stand firm.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He insists a Montague dog would make him stand and fight, and he will take the better path ('take the wall') from any Montague.

speaker: GREGORY
content: He says that taking the wall shows weakness, since the weakest are forced aside.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He twists this to say women, as weaker vessels, are pushed against the wall, so he will push Montague men away and thrust their women to the wall, with sexual implication.

speaker: GREGORY
content: He reminds Sampson the quarrel is between the masters and their servants, not with the women.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He says it is all the same, and he will act like a tyrant: after fighting the men, he will be 'civil' with the maids by cutting off their heads.

speaker: GREGORY
content: He asks for clarification, shocked at the idea of cutting off the maids' heads.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He makes a crude pun, saying he means either their literal heads or their virginity ('maidenheads'), leaving the interpretation open.

speaker: GREGORY
content: He replies that those who feel it will understand the meaning, continuing the sexual jest.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson boasts that his enemies will feel his strength while he can stand, and he is known to be a sturdy man.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory jokes that it's good Sampson isn't a fish, or he'd be poor John—a cheap dried fish—then tells him to draw his sword because Montagues approach.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson says his sword is drawn and he will support Gregory if they quarrel.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory pretends to misunderstand, asking if Sampson means to turn his back and run.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson reassures him not to be afraid.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory replies, 'No, indeed; I'm afraid of you!'—a sarcastic jab.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson suggests they keep the law on their side by letting the Montagues start the fight.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory says he will scowl as he passes, letting the Montagues interpret it as they please.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson escalates, saying he will bite his thumb at them—a rude gesture—which would disgrace them if they tolerate it.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram confronts them, asking if the thumb-biting is directed at them.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson admits he is biting his thumb but avoids saying it's at Abram.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram repeats the question more insistently.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson checks with Gregory if the law supports them if he says yes.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory simply says no.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson backtracks, saying he bites his thumb but not specifically at Abram, trying to avoid legal blame.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory directly asks Abram if he wants to quarrel, pushing the confrontation further.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram denies wanting to quarrel, using 'sir' as a formal but potentially sarcastic address.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson says he will fight if Abram does, and boasts that his master is as good as Abram's, escalating the confrontation.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram dismissively replies 'No better,' challenging Sampson's claim and further provoking him.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson responds with 'Well, sir,' a noncommittal but tense acknowledgment, as Benvolio enters.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory urges Sampson to say 'better' now that a kinsman of their master is approaching, encouraging defiance.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson boldly repeats 'Yes, better, sir,' directly challenging Abram with the kinsman present.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram accuses Sampson of lying, a direct insult that demands a violent response in this code of honor.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson calls them to draw swords if they are men, and reminds Gregory of his 'washing blow'—a slashing strike—as they fight.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio calls them fools and orders them to put away their swords, saying they don't understand the consequences, and beats down their weapons.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt insults Benvolio as drawn among 'heartless hinds'—cowardly servants—and tells him to face his death, showing immediate aggression.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio explains he is only trying to keep peace and urges Tybalt to put up his sword or help separate the fighters.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt scorns the idea of peace while armed, declaring he hates peace as much as hell, all Montagues, and Benvolio, then attacks him as a coward.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet demands to know what the noise is and calls for his long sword, ready to join the fray.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet mocks his call for a sword by saying he needs a crutch instead, highlighting his age and unfitness for fighting.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet insists on his sword, claiming Old Montague has arrived and is waving his blade to insult him.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague calls Capulet a villain and demands to be released so he can fight, showing the family rage is mutual.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
content: She orders her husband not to go looking for a fight, showing her concern for his safety and desire to avoid further conflict.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He asks who reignited the old feud and questions his nephew Benvolio about whether he witnessed the start of the brawl.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He explains that servants from both houses were already fighting when he arrived, and when he tried to intervene, Tybalt appeared and swung his sword harmlessly, provoking more fighting until the Prince stopped it.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
content: She asks where Romeo is and expresses relief that he was not involved in the fight, showing her maternal concern.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He recounts seeing Romeo early in the morning walking alone, but Romeo avoided him by hiding in the woods; Benvolio respected his wish for solitude and did not pursue him.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He describes Romeo’s recent behavior: crying at dawn and locking himself away in darkness once the sun rises, suggesting a deep, troubling melancholy that worries him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks Montague if he knows the cause of Romeo’s sadness.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He replies that he does not know the cause and has not been able to learn it from Romeo.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks whether Montague has pressed Romeo for an explanation.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He says that he and others have tried, but Romeo keeps his feelings secret like a bud damaged by a worm before it can bloom, and they wish they could discover and cure his sorrow.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He notices Romeo approaching and suggests that Montague and Lady Montague leave so he can try to learn Romeo’s troubles privately.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He hopes Benvolio will succeed in hearing Romeo’s true confession and leaves with Lady Montague.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He greets Romeo with 'Good morning, cousin.'

speaker: ROMEO
content: He expresses surprise that it is still so early in the day, showing his distorted sense of time due to sadness.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He confirms that it is only nine o’clock.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He laments that sad hours feel long and asks if that was his father who left quickly, showing his self-absorption and distraction.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks what sorrow is making Romeo’s time pass slowly.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he lacks the thing that, if he had it, would make time fly.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio guesses he is in love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is out—meaning out of love’s favor.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks if he is out of love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo clarifies he is out of favor with the woman he loves.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio laments that love seems gentle but proves harsh and cruel in experience.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo complains that blind love still finds ways to get what it wants. He abruptly asks where to eat, then reflects on the earlier brawl, saying it relates to hate but more to love. He exclaims over love’s contradictions—brawling yet loving, created from nothing, heavy yet light, serious yet vain, chaos in pleasing shapes, leaden feather, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health, and waking sleep that is not what it seems. He says he feels this kind of love but no joy in it, and asks if Benvolio is laughing.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says no, cousin, he would rather weep.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks why, addressing Benvolio affectionately as 'Good heart'.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says he weeps at the suffering of Romeo’s good heart.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says that is how love wrongs us. His own grief weighs on him, and Benvolio’s sympathy will only add more sorrow to his burden. He describes love as a smoke made from sighs; when cleared, a fire in lovers’ eyes; when troubled, a sea fed by lovers’ tears. It is also a wise madness, a bitter poison, and a preserving sweetness. He says farewell and starts to leave.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says wait, he will go with Romeo, and it would be wrong to leave him like this.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses this, saying he has lost himself and is not really here; Romeo is somewhere else.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks him seriously to say who he loves.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo replies sarcastically, asking if he should groan while telling him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks Romeo to tell him seriously who he loves, since Romeo is groaning.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He compares his lovesickness to a sick man making a will, then admits he loves a woman.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He says he guessed correctly that Romeo was in love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He confirms Benvolio’s guess and says the woman he loves is beautiful.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He jokes that a beautiful target is easiest to hit with love’s arrow.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says she cannot be won by love: she is chaste like Diana, immune to flattery, gazes, or riches, and her beauty will die with her.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks if she has sworn to remain chaste.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He confirms her vow wastes her beauty by leaving no heirs, and her perfection causes his despair, making him feel dead while alive.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He advises Romeo to forget her.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks how he can possibly stop thinking of her.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He suggests looking at other beautiful women.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He argues that comparing others to her only makes him remember her more, like a blind man cannot forget lost sight, and any beauty just reminds him of her.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He vows to prove his advice works or die trying, showing his determination to help.
